summary: Stephanie Zinone (Michelle Pfeiffer) is the leader of Rydell High School's Pink Ladies, a gang of girls who are counterparts of the school's group of greasers called the T-Birds. Stephanie is tired of her relationship with top T-Bird Johnny Nogerelli (Adrian Zmed), so she breaks up with him and quickly catches the eye of English exchange student Michael Carrington (Maxwell Caulfield). Hoping to win her over, Michael tries to overcome his nerdy ways while holding off the jealous Johnny.

reviews.content: The worst sequel that doesn't f**king deserve the 01 hour: and 55 minutes ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

It's great fun, camp with catchy songs. The genders have been flipped and this time the Pink Ladies are the strong, hard to get characters. It's got some great sign-alongs songs and is tongue in cheek silliness which movies can be (they don't always have to be Shindlers List). Musicals are usually cringeworthy anyway but this sequel poked fun at itself and has some decent iconic scenes. Have some fun and take it for what it is ... entertaining fun!

I'm a big fan of cheese and a big fan of silly musicals so this movie for me takes the cake. It's probably up there as one of my faves. I can understand why there are negative reviews, but I think most people take this film too seriously. It's not as grotesque and horrendous as people make out (you'd think the film committed some sort of heinous crime). 

I enjoyed everything! From the cringey cool guy motorcycle scenes and the awful romance songs. If you're looking for an easy and fun watch this is a great choice! I've watched it three times in two days and can't stop singing "Cool Rider"
The songs did not resonate with the Grease vibe at all. The cast, the script could have been better.
Not as good as the first. Should have kept it at 1
I think this movie is ok no is a Masterpiece but is nice

Very underrated film, great script, great songs and choreography.
I was a little hesitant to watch it a first because of the negative views I heard from people, decided to watch it and it's fair to say they were all wrong. Great movie overall, love it.

First, not sure if pink leather existed in the 1950s, I could be wrong.  But where the first had unforgettable earworms that stayed with you.  The music here was lackluster.  Not horrible mind you, just not to the level of the first movie.  Like the first movie, it's also too long for the story they were telling with too many needless subplots.  But considering how beloved the first movie was it is impossible to even come close to it let alone surpass it.  Now it has it's good point.  The dances are impressive as well as the cast.  The story is a bit of rehash but it has some great jokes.  So not as bad as critics tell you but not good either, it's just meh.

This is horrible.  The only guy that can sing is the guy that played Louis.  Michelle and Maxwell were good.  The lady that played Frenchie was amazing. The pink ladies were not bad.  All the T-Birds (minus the guy that played Louis) were horrible and the guy that played Tony was the worst, his acting and singing really killed the movie. So bad.  I struggled to finish it. I wish I could give it no stars.

Would give absolute 0 if I could it's an embarrassing follow up to original. This film should never have been released songs with no tune and worst acting ever . Seriously I worry about anyone who even would rate this garbage as even remotely decent . Will never live up to the original Grease I feel embarrassed for those who acted in this film as so should they
The music is awesome and the costumes are bananas good. Two of the most gorgeous humans on the planet and lots of laughs. This movie is so underrated.
I've always loved this movie and still enjoy it today! The songs are so up beat and catchy, you can't help but develop an earworm
The worst 01 hour: and 55 minutes ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
loved it have watched it time & time again

Working from a script by Jaime Comas Gil (A Fistful of Dollars, the insane Adam and Eve vs. the Cannibals) and Eugenio Benito, this starts with stock footage of modern life that's soon blown asunder by b-roll and stock footage, signaling that the end times have come and gone*. Soon enough, Rage (Bruno Minniti, who was the hero in just about every Ricci movie from Thor the Conqueror on; he used the name Conrad Nichols in nearly all of them) must lead Werner, Omar and Mara through the Forbidden Zone to get uranium and battle the man he gave a scar -- and the name Scar -- and an entire army of his motocross soldiers and you know what this is all about? A cryo chamber with a Bible in it. Can Rage and his team take a train across the wasteland and deliver the Good News from Alpha Base to Gamma Base?
I absolutely love both grease and grease 2
This movie is pretty bad. But, it has a lot of catchy songs that I still remembered from when I viewed it as a kid.
Hollywood made a mistake hoping to catch the sequel to the almighty "Grease".

This movie would've been better off being turned into a stand-alone film rather than being a stand-alone sequel to one of the highest-grossing movies of 1978. Because Grease 2 actually has its merits. The songs are really fun, even if they don't have the same staying power as "Grease is the Word" and "Summer Nights" and the choreography is pretty darn good, especially during the musical number set in a bowling alley. The performances aren't that bad either, there are some decent scenes and I laughed a few times when the movie delivered humour. But the problem is that it's nature as a Grease sequel keeps holding it down. There's the expected role reprisals from a few supporting characters, of course. Then there's the ill-advised decision to have the protagonist be a distant cousin of Sandy from the last movie which is only established in one line of dialogue making one wonder why they didn't have him be just a foreign exchange student in the first place. And no sequel would be complete without rehashing the plot of the first film, just with genders switching places. It adds some variety to the proceedings but not enough to set it apart from its beloved predecessor. Also, the gangs are a bit wimpier, at least by comparison to their predecessors. The songs can get rather out of hand at times as well. One thing I hated about them was how the songs interrupted themselves to make room for dialogue while the BGM is still playing. It tended to take me out of the movie. After seeing and reviewing this movie, I have now come to the conclusion that Grease 2 is a crappy sequel but a passable stand-alone musical that isn't entirely undeserving of scorn but didn't really strike me for a candidate of "Top 5 worst musicals of all time" either.

I had long ago heard about this movie being way worse than the original, but now that I've seen it the gap in quality is really not that bad. It's certainly a step down, but the best part of the first movie was never the acting talent or the actual plot but rather the energy put into the song and dance numbers and this movie just about matches the original in that category. They used the same choreographer (who also served as director for this one) and, while the songs were certainly not as catchy, the cast really committed themselves and the dancing was great. The main problem is that the plot itself is incredibly banal, with stakes perhaps lower than I've ever seen in a movie before. The girl was supremely shallow and didn't deserve the leading man, leaving no hope that their relationship would last and no room for any emotional investment by the audience. Even the songs were about practically nothing whatsoever most of the time. This movie tests my willingness to base my rating mostly on the viewing experience when the technical merits are lacking as I liked the choreography enough to gloss over the issues with the plot and enjoy watching the movie, but in this case the problems are too severe to ignore. Shoot!
3.0/10. this is one of the worst musicals I've ever seen. the songs are all forgettable, the characters and rec-casts are no way near as good as the original and is a very boring movie.
The sequel is worse than its predecessor!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Great plot songs and everything who wouldn't love this!

I wish to first state that when is saw there was a Grease 2 and it didn't have the original cast I almost cried in fear if it ruining the original, and I was very disappointed with almost every feature of this movie, I don't see how people can watch this or how any of the (few returning) original actors agreed to be in it, it is a disgrace to movies and in fact I made an account on this site just for this because I will not let my views on this mess go unnoticed.
Not as much singing and dancing, songs are recycled, and the movie revolves around a talent show. This sequel is not as good as the original.

The sequel nobody needed at all.. Ok, there are some songs that are wonderfully useless from the beggening to the end, their music numbers do not provide anything to the movie as a whole, neither the coreography is something that deserves praising most if them end up being just embarassing. There Is almost no story to process on this film, It feels forced and without any real purpouse.  As for the characters none of them has a real and credible personality, there Is no Sense of empathy from the viewer towards the main couple because of the poor acting they show and the lack of contexto for the plot, It does not feel natural It just becames ridicule in the end.
One of the worst cash grabs of all time.

I don't know if I've ever made it all the way through this movie in a single sitting. Honestly, the things that are bad about the movie so overwhelm what's likeable that it's hard to know where to start. The opening is not exactly terrible, though it's also miles below its predecessor. Watching it, you can mentally check off everything that falls below "Grease." Male lead? Check. Adrian Zmed is no John Travolta. Female lead? Check. Michelle Pfeiffer would become a huge star, but she wasn't there in this movie. Music? Check. the opening number of "Back to School" has its moments (especially in the choreography, largely because both movies had the same choreographer - Patricia Birch, who also directed "Grease 2.") The Pink Ladies? Check. Even without a middle-aged leader (Stockard Channing, who was grossly miscast), these Pink Ladies have very little appeal. The T-Birds? Check. The T-Birds of Grease were definitely the coolest guys in school. These birds are slightly more cool than Eugene. And they bowl. They all bowl. Not that there's anything wrong with bowling, but when bowling is the coolest thing to do when you're in high school, there's definitely something wrong. And that's where I always tend to stop watching this movie. When the film moves to "We're Gonna Score Tonight" (the big bowling musical number), my stomach begins to turn and I have to turn the TV off, or at least to another channel. This number was intended to be naughty with its not-so-subtle double entendres, but it really just comes across as stupid. Yes, I have ultimately watched the entire movie, and it's all just a cheap substitute for the original "Grease." If they'd taken some more time to write some decent songs, and if they'd written an actual screenplay with interesting characters, making a "Grease" sequel would have been worthwhile. Instead, we have "Grease 2," which isn't even worthwhile for viewing in a single sitting.
For the life of me, I can't understand why they made this film. I also can't understand why I watched it to the end.

My favorite Grease movie!!  I have loved this movie since it came to HBO back in the day cuz I was too young to see it in the theater.  (My VHS tape of this movie eventually died because I watched it all the time.) To me it is dreamy. I love the characters, soundtrack, dancing, and theme of the movie.  In fact, I always wanted my name to be Stephanie, or at least name my children Stephanie or Michael when I had them because of this movie.  Luckily, I was able to give my son the middle name Michael :) 

Yes, it is not "Grease"  but I am more than OK with that because it is two years later and it would be weird for Danny and Sandy to be hanging out at their old high school post graduation unless they were teachers. Again, quit comparing it to "Grease."  I also liked that some of the minor characters from Grease were in this movie, like Principal McGee, Blanche, Coach Calhoun, Eugene, and of course Frenchy to tie it back to Grease, but it is separate movie and not a continuation of Grease.  

Also, this movie focuses more on the Pink Ladys and girl power than the T-Birds!!  For example, Stephanie questions being in a relationship with Johnny, and she wants something more in life than just making out.  As a young girl watching this movie, it was empowering because most movies at the time taught girls that their happiness relied on a man.  

So, see this movie!!  You might find yourself wanting a cool, cool, cool rider or a girl for all seasons :)

This sequel to the 1978 classic is actually an entertaining film with some pretty decent songs. You could tell Michelle Pfeiffer was on her way to stardom. Maxwell Caulfield and Adrian Zmed weren't too bad either in their roles.
Dancing and songs very good. A young Michelle Pfeiffer showed promise, doing her own singing.
Proof that not every movie deserves a sequel.
I prefer it to Grease one. Michelle Pfeiffer on a ladder. 😍
Best Movie ever made. This was a massive hit in India in early 90s. We friends must have seen it perhaps 100 times in theatres !
Love this movie and love the music, it is the perfect 80s musical, cheesy and fun.

Entertaining but very weak story, lousy music, and very forgettable characters with some low-rate acting. "Grease 2" really should have never been made, but it's certainly fun to watch simply to laugh at how bad it is, and to remind everyone just how great/legendary its predecessor "Grease" really was
Only reason it got a 1/2 star, was because the first one helped it a bit. Other than that, this is a horrible sequel

It's so awful, I thought it was intended to be a farce of the original. It's so bad, it's funny.

despite some beautiful songs and well done choreographies.Grease 2 was a disappointment compared to its predecessor.presents a predictable plot, sexist dialogues
and almost repeats the same story from the first sequel. When I first saw it I thought it was good, but when I watched it for the second time comparing with the first one I found it much lower, even Michelle Pfeiffer as the beginning of her career.

If you go into this movie expecting to see "Grease", then you will not be impressed. Sure, the school is the same, the stables of "the T birds" and "the Pink Lady's" are still there with some characters from the first one rehashed as well, This movie does get a lot of criticism, as people tend to compare it to its predecessor, which is not fair...to an extent. Though the story is generally the same as the first one, it is not told the same however, rather than two people changing to try to win the love of the other, "Grease 2" only really sees one person trying to change to win the other. This movie is long, some of the dance numbers are vastly drawn out for what seems like no reason. The music is not terrible and performed well, with the given material. The same can be said about the acting. The actors do a decent job with the given material. Director Patrica Birch (who also worked on the first one) does a passable job as director, in fact, the direction is not bad at all with the story she was working with. If you go in expecting to see the first one, you will not enjoy it. As a child, I loved this movie, as I also loved the first one. Now, as an adult, I would not say I still love it, but it is enjoyable to watch. Its worth watching at least once, if you are into musicals. If you found the first one to just be "okay", do not watch it, you will hate it.
I loved this movie! It was so much better, then the 1st one! I love the whole movie from beginning to the end! I loved Michelle Pfeiffer, she was my favorite one in this movie!

This movie is the GREASIEST movie that I have ever seen. There were so many hot chicks in it and the main character is really sexy. It had so much kissing and the acting was just amazing. This movie is ten times better than Infinity War, but that's because Infinity War sucks.

completely loved this move Michelle was my Idol i actually enjoyed her more then sandy and prefered grease 2 songs over grease the original. I am still a huge fan of grease 2 i just wanted to actually be michelle hahaha. I don't understand why people didn't love this i was obsessed and still am

One of the more underrated sequels. Maxwell Caulfied delievers a performance of sincerity and class. His screen presence is up there with Travolta although his acting needed improvement. The songs are catchy and the dance numbers are incredible. I highly respect this film.

Is it as good as the original? No. but it's unfairly panned as a complete waste of time, when it isn't. It's got some catchy numbers and some corny fun moments. Might help that I first viewed it as a kid, where I thought high school was going to be just like what I saw onscreen. Boy how wrong I was...haha

Grease 2 is a romantic comedy musical that is severely overlooked. A sequel to the adaptation of the Broadway show Grease, it stars Maxwell Caulfield and Michelle Pfeiffer, two powerhouse singers who have electric chemistry on-screen. Grease 2 has a deep emotional range, with upbeat songs about lust ("Prowlin'") and slow ballads about the hardships of being yourself ("Charades"). The movie is not without laughs, the song "Reproduction" always draws at least a chuckle from the most stoic of viewers.
The writing is also very comedic, with witty banter flying between the characters. One of my personal favorite scenes is toward the beginning, when the Pink Ladies (Stephanie, Rhonda, Paulette, and Sharon) are standing at their lockers, and the T-Birds (Johnnie, Goose, Louis, and Davey) have just left with the parting words "You may turn up on the Bandstand, but your beak will still be turning DOWN," in reference to Rhonda's nose. The following hilarious exchange occurs:

Rhonda: That's it. The nose goes. Bandstand, here I come.
Paulette: Rhonda, I wouldn't fool around with mother nature if I were you.
Sharon: You fooled around with everyone else, Paulette.
Paulette: Oh shut up.

There are also a lot of social issues addressed in Grease 2, such as pressuring a partner into sex, possessiveness over how a partner dresses and acts, and changing yourself to fit social expectations. There is a happy ending, with all couples agreeing to meet in the middle, and during the song "We'll Be Together" they each have a conversation about the above issues, and they are all resolved.
Many people dismiss Grease 2 as a bad sequel to a classic movie, but I bet most of them haven't given it a chance. It's a goofy movie, sure, and the plot isn't genius, but it's entertaining and the music is very catchy. If you liked Grease, then you are sure to like Grease 2.
I think this film is underrated! I love the plot, the songs, the actors and everything about it! It's a great sequel!
An astounding miss in so many ways. A sequel to the classic Grease... in 1961?!?! Put this in your Bad Movie Night rotation. YW.

Grease 2 is one of the most underrated movies of all-time. It has solid songs (Cool Rider, Reproduction) and one of the best dance numbers ever captured on film (Score Tonight). It is decidedly more feminist than the original, and the performances are every bit as good. Given a choice between watching Grease and Grease 2, I'll choose 2 every time. Also, Michelle Pfeiffer and Maxwell Caulfield heat up the screen!

This is a slightly less original version of the first one & could easily be seen as a retread. There aren't too many changes except for the role reversal of the main characters and if you really liked everything Grease, you may well in fact like this one too. Cheap mindless entertainment is fun sometimes & exactly what you are looking for. Have a great day!

I'm not sure why people dislike this movie so much. Of course it doesn't compare to the first, but it is still an entertaining movie.
The songs are very catchy and I like the humor.

D+
While the songs in 'Grease 2' are catchy, they certainly aren't as memorable as the songs from the first film (sans 'Reproduction'), and although it is good to see a few of the original cast members back for this sequel, 'Grease 2' just doesn't feel like 'Grease' to me. It's just another guy-tries-to-impress-girl-by-being-someone-else movie. It's as disappointing of a guilty pleasure as it is.

I grew up with it. Saw iyt first in 1982, and I've actually studied parts of the movie over the past year, noting stuff I'd never seen or paid attention to before. I see a lot in the movie that others wouldn't because it wasn't the first Grease. Besides I'm on a Facebook friendship with one of the dancers who helped me tremendously with a for-fun Grease 2 storybook I'm working on, basically the entire movie word-for-word. Grease 2 isn't as magical as Grease was but it's as funny and quirky.

As someone who loves and I mean loves the original grease movie I didn't know if I'd love this just as much or if Id dislike this. Unfortunately it did very poorly and nothing beats the original. Grease live was better than this but the original grease movie is #1

Grease 2: Yes, it's a retread of its wildly popular predecessor with the sex roles reversed, and yes, it lacks the star power of the original, but that said, the film has song very catchy songs and is entertaining in its own right, with Michelle Pfeiffer as the head of Pink Ladies "gang" who is swept off her feet by a cute but oh-so-wholesome Brit (Maxwell Cauffield) who just transferred to Rydell High. B
Grease 2 is a blatant rehash of the first movie it's the same thing but with stupid/unlikeable main characters and blaring plot holes

I didn't really like Grease 2, I prefer the original Grease over it. The main reason was the story line, it wasn't as strong as I was hoping for. It was simple and predictable, Michael wanted Stephanie but she kept rejecting and treating him horribly basically saying he wasn't cool enough for her, so he set out to become what she wanted "a cool rider". And of course as expected, they end up together at the very end, just because Stephanie realizes it's actually been Michael who is this mysterious "cool rider" on a motorcycle that she keeps thinking about. I felt like the story line was weak and the ending was very predictable.

Grease 2 is a perfect example of a disastrous sequel. I didn't find the original to hold anything special except its still growing legacy - the second one is absolutely horrid, with such a bland atmosphere and characters you won't care about (especially the 5 or so actors they got to return only briefly), Grease 2 is one of the worst in '80s cheese and one of the worst sequels ever.
Grease 2 holds no real resemblances to the first, except for the school. Characters you may have liked are all gone, instead replacing Danny with the nerdy British exchange student Michael and Sandy with the most popular girl in school, Stephanie - it's a role reversal plot at its worst, and there's tons of bad suspense points cheesy dialogue, tie-ins to the early '60s, it's all so bleak and bland that it looks like a bootleg ripoff.
Grease 2 is the worst kind of film cheese, with everything wrong about the original times ten. Those who even say Pfeiffer's performance was a redeeming factor are wrong - it's a boring way to cash in more on the franchise nobody wanted a sequel for. Grease 2 is one of the all time worst...

Liked it more than the first one tbh. I guess I felt more identified by the nice guy trying to be the bad boy story. Building his own motorcycle from scratch, keeping good grades and getting the hottest girl at the end ?? One of my favorites. Dont get me wrong tho, the first was good but this one rocked better to me. ( No hate and enjoy both of em. ;) )

the not worst movie i have ever seen but we remember so much from the first movie but so little from this one this one feel forgettable and predictable and romance is smiler to one you would see in a superhero movie the only thing i like was the sound track in some ways you can call it a  vintage High School Musical
Amazing movie! Honestly appalled that nobody recognizes its charm. Great acting, singing, and fun storyline. Great continuation to Grease! Don't care what anybody says

really love it and want to see it

What I got to say about "Grease 2" is that it's a okay of a movie. The performances by the cast is great. The directing by Patricia Birch is good. The screenplay is fine. Cinematography in this movie is good as well. Choreography is outstanding. And the score in this is good. Now the only negative problem that I have to report is for my opinion, there are some moments in the movie that slows down and take a little bit to pick the pace back up.
Great sequel. Worth watching!
Good movie it's a must see!.
sooo much bettah then the 1st one! i love maxwelllll colfelld

Watching "Grease 2" is pretty much like ordering a hot dog and only getting the bun. There is nothing flavorful and fresh to offer, and it looks half-baked, as if they just did the whole film in two takes. 

The male lead looks completely disinterested in being on film, and it really doesn't help that the story is just a diluted version of the 1978 classic. 

The stupid songs, on the other hand, sound like something that came out of a high school chorus rendering of a '50's doo wop medley. 

To sum it up, the whole thing was atrocious. "Grease 2" makes "High School Musical: Senior Year" look like an Oscar contender. That is how low this movie can go.
Cheesy.com love it !!!!

This Was a great movie and it is so so so great and it was great !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Completely unimpressed by the lack of originality and overrated reviews of the awful musical film Grease, I figured Grease 2 couldn't be any worse, and it did feature a young role for 3 time Academy Award nominee Michelle Pfeiffer so for some reason I just went ahead and watched it.

From the mere intro of Grease 2, it is instantly apparent that the film is going to be bad. It breaks out into a senseless dance sequence with a song that isn't catchy and a bunch of teenagers prancing around. But then again, this is the exact same crap that Grease presented to viewers in 1978.
Grease 2 is a bad idea from the start because a sequel to a musical film is never a good idea. That is why the relatively unknown sequel to The Rocky Horror Picture Show entitled Shock Treatment was so unsuccessful, and so a sequel to Grease is not a better idea. I hated Grease anyway, so I pretty much just went in with hopes that I could tolerate this one more than the its predecessor which had its hype drilled into my head by all the Australian morning news shows boasting about how we should be proud of Olivia Newton-John's success when it was from a 36 year old film which is dated and crappy. But it was my opinion that with Michelle Pfeiffer cast in the lead role it couldn't be worse than Grease.
The story in Grease 2 is slightly better than its predecessor because the love story is slightly less repetitive, generic and overused, although it still is of rather poor calibre. Grease 2 is a thinly written film with a dull script and another cheap plot which it milks for all it can yet pretty much comes up dry the whole time. And all the colourful costumes and scenery as well as the fine cinematography is not enough to mask the fact that underneath, Grease 2 is too formulaic and dim-witted to satisfy anyone but the most die hard fans of Grease, but the paper thin writing and weakly sketched characters as well as a distinct lack of originality was not enough for me.
I didn't like the songs in Grease because I found that they were generic and repetitive, so of course I found that to be the case in Grease 2, only that they were even worse this time around because the songs were retreading old material without a hint of originality or creativity in them. I didn't like any of the music in Grease 2 except the song "Cool Rider" which was rather catchy and sung very well by Michelle Pfeiffer despite not being so well written. The music in Grease 2 is unforgettable and generic, but at least it wasn't as irritating as the music in the first Grease.
In the end, the only really appealing aspect of Grease 2 is its cast, and while it doesn't save the film from collapsing under its own mediocrity it at least makes the screen a bit brighter when its stuck under stiff and dark direction from Patricia Birch who in her one effort as a film director turns weak material into misguided cinema.
Michelle Pfeiffer's character is a superior character to Olivia Newton-John's in Grease because her character is an independent woman who doesn't rely on a boyfriend for social standards or happiness, while Olivia Newton-John's character was one that suggested to women everywhere that you should sacrifice who you are and everything you believe in for some man you think you love during your teenage years. Michelle Pfeiffer's performance is better than Olivia Newton-John's for a lot of reasons, with a lot of them being that her singing voice is excellent and sung way better than the screechy high pitched lyrics that Olivia Newton-John stuck into the ears of viewers in the first Grease. Michelle Pfeiffer's youthful charisma and dedication to the part manages to lighten up the screen in Grease 2, and it proves early on the talented actress she would later go on to become.
Maxwell Caulfield's rising career was ruined by Grease 2 which was a shame because he is a strong cast member. He doesn't have the same charm that John Travolta had, but his character isn't as stuck up or arrogant as John Travolta's was so it was easier for me to tolerate him. I found that I was able to sympathise for him and that his intentions as a man of romance were less generic and more meaningful, if a little melodramatic at times. Also, his singing voice has a certain quaint sophistication to him. So Maxwell Caulfield is a good choice for the lead in Grease 2.
Christopher McDonald is an underrated actor in my opinion, so it's good to see him taking on a role in Grease 2 in his youth because his natural acting charisma and his ability to act stuck up well manages to benefit his characterisation of Goose McKenzie well. He is a notable addition to the cast.
And it's good to see Maureen Teefy taking on another role after her great performance in the musical classic Fame. It gives her a chance to show off her charismatic skills as a young actress as well as her beautiful singing voice once again even though she is working with weak material and low quality song writing. She is a charming face in Grease 2 and makes the experience more entertaining.

But while Grease 2 boasts the strength of a dedicated cast and a charming performance from a young Michelle Pfeiffer before her international breakthrough as an actress, Grease 2 has the same essential problems of its crappy predecessor without the kinetic energy that made it iconic. And as a person who avidly hated the first Grease, I can say that at best, Grease 2 is only slightly better than Grease because the music wasn't ear piercing, the story wasn't as painfully generic and the leads are a lot more likeable this time around.
Grease 2 is pretty bad, but I love it just the same.

It took everything we loved about "Grease" and threw it out the window. With this lousy sequel, we get a boring and badly acted cast, few memorable songs, and a ridiculous plot. I've never facepalmed so hard in my life.

Though nowhere near as good as the original 1978 film, it still has enough charm to entertain fans of the original. Michelle Pfeiffer and Maxwell Caulfield are likeable enough as the leads. Although there are a few less than stellar musical numbers ("Prowling", "Rock a Hula Lua"), there are some bright spots ("Back to School Again", "Reproduction",and Love WIll Turn Back The Hands of Time"). Although the film suffers from some really poor editing, the majority of the film is enjoyable.

In 1961, two years after "Sandy", "Danny" and the gang from Rydell High School graduated and went on with their lives, we return to the school on the first day of the school year with a new group of students, along with some familiar faces.

"Michael" (Maxwell Caulfield), the British cousin of "Sandy", arrives on the first day as students are dancing and singing. He is met by "Frenchy" (Didi Conn), the "Beauty School Dropout" who is returning to start her career in cosmetology by learning high school chemistry.

Soon after arriving, he bumps into the beautiful "Stephanie" (Michelle Pfeiffer, in her first starring role), who is the leader of the girls gang the "Pink Ladies," and the latest girl of "Johnny" (Adrian Zmed), the leader of the "T-Birds", a gang once lead by "Danny" in the original movie.

It is love at first sight for the well-mannered young man, but he quickly learns that he has to be a "T-Bird" to date her. But, he will do anything to get close to her.

Now, "Michael" pursues his crush by turning into what "Stephanie" wants -- a "cool rider" who will sweep her off her feet.

Let me say right off the bat, this is a very weak followup to one of the greatest musicals of all time. It just completely lacks the magic of the original film.

First of all, there is the music. If you ask me, only two of the 13 songs are memorable. The rest, though having the sound of early-60's music, is just terrible and uninspired. To me, most of the tunes sounded as if they were just thrown together just before production starts. As for the choreography in these scenes, it's hit or miss. In the original, we get an energetic dance number in the school gym, which is one of the most memorable moments in the movie. In Grease 2, we get an out-of-nowhere number in the local bowling alley that the cast appeared to enjoy doing. However, I would not want to go back to learn these steps (and I am in a wheelchair). I also felt, with some exceptions, that the cast was taught the choreography the day before filming the dance scenes.

One of the biggest problems is character development. To me, the characters seemed to have been written as if we are expected to know the new faces. Most of the main characters appear to be loosely based on specific characters from the first film (most notably "Michael," a male version of "Sandy" with a bit of "Danny" thrown in, and "Stephanie", a female version of "Danny" with a bit of "Sandy" thrown in). There are also many supporting characters with their own, minor story lines which barely moves the story along. We get only minor basics of these characters, and the audience mostly ignores them due to not being presented well.

As for performances from the main cast, they are fairly good, but not perfect. Pfeiffer is near perfect in her first major role on the silver screen, and carries the weaker members of the cast fairly well in their scenes together -- and she can actually carry a tune pretty well (especially in "Cool Rider," one of the only two songs you will most likely remember after the closing credits end. Caulfield was pretty good as "Michael", even in his invented alter-ego to swoon "Stephanie". However, there was something lacking in their romantic chemistry most of the time.

The supporting cast, all around, is quite weak. Like I said, these characters are horribly written. We only get the most basic information. The "T-Birds" lacked the feel of being a unit, as did the "Pink Ladies." We even get some of the original cast in this film, but they are only on-screen to deliver a line or two as the movie progresses.

As for the wardrobes, nothing real special here. The gym shirts the men wear in one scene appear to have the school name ironed onto it, and not in a quality a school district would spend the money on. I found the wardrobe pretty boring actually. The "Pink Ladies" and "T-Birds" iconic jackets don't look that great on the cast members wearing them. And, especially with certain male members of the cast, the hairdos look too much teased. It looked as if they cut some corners on the wardrobes and hairdos to me.

The story just feels rushed, especially the part where "Michael" creates his alter-ego. It appears that he became an expert in riding rather quickly, as there was no way to tell how much time had past.

I really can't recommend this one. If you already own the first movie, I would suggest that you get this film just so you can have both movies. And that's the only reason to purchase it. It's just not able to live up to the icon that is the original.

A late night no-brainer that I pulled out of the archives recently. Ok so it's not a classic and it's not the finest quality cinema on offer, but it's cheesy and it's 80s (set in 60s but doesn't achieve believability that grease did). The songs are pretty bad but still funny to watch, Cool Rider is a classic with Michelle Pfeiffer straddling the top of a ladder, it's gooey cheese at it's best. Don't watch this and compare with Grease, it's a whole different ball game. Instead of cars its motorbikes this time, see it took some clever people a long time to think of that one :)

In an attempt to topple its predecessor, Grease 2 fails to concoct even a remotely decent storyline. The progressive, incoherent plot and faltering chemistry only taints the name of this famed musical. Arguably one the worse, if not, the worst sequel in the history of film. .5/5
